stdmodsem

Shu Fai Cheung

2022-07-27

Source: vignettes/stdmodsem.Rmd
stdmodsem.Rmd

Introduction

This article is a brief illustration on how stdmodsem functions are used in some typical cases.

Moderated Mediation

This is the sample dataset comes with the package:

library(stdmodsem)
dat <- data_med_mod_ab
print(head(dat), digits = 3)
#>       x   w1   w2    m    y    c1   c2
#> 1  9.27 4.97 2.66 3.46 8.80  9.26 3.14
#> 2 10.79 4.13 3.33 4.05 7.37 10.71 5.80
#> 3 11.10 5.91 3.32 4.04 8.24 10.60 5.45
#> 4  9.53 4.78 2.32 3.54 8.37  9.22 3.83
#> 5 10.00 4.38 2.95 4.65 8.39  9.58 4.26
#> 6 12.25 5.81 4.04 4.73 9.65  9.51 4.01

Suppose this is the model being fitted:

This is a moderated mediation model with

  • a mediation path x -> m -> y, and

  • two moderators: x -> m moderated by w1 and m -> y moderated by w2.

The effects of interest are the conditional indirect effects: the indirect effects from x to y through m for different levels of w1 and w2.

There are two common approaches to test and estimate these effects: regression approach and structural equation modelling approach. The following sections will illustrate these two approaches.

Multiple Regression by lm() 

lm_m <- lm(m ~ x * w1, dat)
lm_y <- lm(y ~ m * w2 + x, dat)

These are the coefficients:

printCoefmat(summary(lm_m)$coefficients, digits = 3, signif.legend = FALSE)
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)  
#> (Intercept)  11.6273     4.8501    2.40    0.018 *
#> x            -0.6342     0.5006   -1.27    0.208  
#> w1           -2.2551     0.9654   -2.34    0.022 *
#> x:w1          0.1998     0.0958    2.09    0.040 *
printCoefmat(summary(lm_y)$coefficients, digits = 3, signif.legend = FALSE)
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)   8.1648     1.2779    6.39  6.2e-09 ***
#> m            -0.0936     0.2763   -0.34   0.7357    
#> w2           -0.8784     0.3409   -2.58   0.0115 *  
#> x             0.0599     0.0892    0.67   0.5038    
#> m:w2          0.1926     0.0726    2.65   0.0094 **

To compute conditional indirect effects and form bootstrap confidence intervals, we use cond_indirect_effects(). For a model with coefficients estimate by multiple regression, we first group the lm() outputs to a list.

This can be done by lm2list(), which will also check the lm() outputs to see whether they can from a model and whether exactly the cases are used in all models:

fit_lm <- lm2list(lm_m, lm_y)
fit_lm
#> 
#> The models:
#> m ~ x * w1
#> y ~ m * w2 + x

We then use mod_levels_list() to generate combinations of levels of the moderators, 1 SD below and above means in this example by setting sd_from_mean:

mod_levels <- mod_levels_list("w1", "w2",
                              fit = fit_lm,
                              sd_from_mean = c(-1, 1),
                              merge = TRUE)
mod_levels
#>                                w1       w2
#> w1: M+1.0SD; w2: M+1.0SD 6.173157 4.040487
#> w1: M+1.0SD; w2: M-1.0SD 6.173157 2.055091
#> w1: M-1.0SD; w2: M+1.0SD 4.038047 4.040487
#> w1: M-1.0SD; w2: M-1.0SD 4.038047 2.055091

To form bootstrapping confidence intervals, we first repeat the regression analysis in all models by nonparametric bootstrapping and store the results. This can be done by lm2boot_out():

(Note: Only 500 bootstrap samples are used for illustration. Set R to 2000 or even 5000 in real research.)

fit_lm_boot_out <- lm2boot_out(fit_lm, R = 500, seed = 87415)

It is all set. We can now compute the conditional indirect effect:

out_lm <- cond_indirect_effects(wlevels = mod_levels,
                             x = "x",
                             y = "y",
                             m = "m",
                             fit = fit_lm,
                             boot_ci = TRUE,
                             boot_out = fit_lm_boot_out)
out_lm
#> 
#> == Conditional indirect effects ==
#> 
#>  Path: x -> m -> y
#>  Conditioned on moderator(s): w1, w2
#>  Moderator(s) represented by: w1, w2
#> 
#>      [w1]    [w2]  (w1)  (w2)   ind  CI.lo CI.hi Sig   m~x   y~m
#> 1 M+1.0SD M+1.0SD 6.173 4.040 0.410 -0.369 1.667     0.599 0.685
#> 2 M+1.0SD M-1.0SD 6.173 2.055 0.181 -0.216 1.062     0.599 0.302
#> 3 M-1.0SD M+1.0SD 4.038 4.040 0.118 -0.658 1.196     0.173 0.685
#> 4 M-1.0SD M-1.0SD 4.038 2.055 0.052 -0.347 0.749     0.173 0.302
#> 
#>  - [CI.lo to CI.hi] are 95.0% percentile confidence intervals by
#>    nonparametric bootstrapping with 500 samples.
#>  - The 'ind' column shows the indirect effects.
#>  - 'm~x','y~m' is/are the path coefficient(s) along the path conditional
#>    on the moderators.

These are the standardized conditional indirect effects:

out_lm_std <- cond_indirect_effects(wlevels = mod_levels,
                             x = "x",
                             y = "y",
                             m = "m",
                             fit = fit_lm,
                             boot_ci = TRUE,
                             boot_out = fit_lm_boot_out,
                             standardized_x = TRUE,
                             standardized_y = TRUE)
out_lm_std
#> 
#> == Conditional indirect effects ==
#> 
#>  Path: x -> m -> y
#>  Conditioned on moderator(s): w1, w2
#>  Moderator(s) represented by: w1, w2
#> 
#>      [w1]    [w2]  (w1)  (w2)   std  CI.lo CI.hi Sig   m~x   y~m   ind
#> 1 M+1.0SD M+1.0SD 6.173 4.040 0.412 -0.359 1.793     0.599 0.685 0.410
#> 2 M+1.0SD M-1.0SD 6.173 2.055 0.182 -0.211 1.227     0.599 0.302 0.181
#> 3 M-1.0SD M+1.0SD 4.038 4.040 0.119 -0.651 1.351     0.173 0.685 0.118
#> 4 M-1.0SD M-1.0SD 4.038 2.055 0.052 -0.334 0.810     0.173 0.302 0.052
#> 
#>  - [CI.lo to CI.hi] are 95.0% percentile confidence intervals by
#>    nonparametric bootstrapping with 500 samples.
#>  - std: The standardized indirect effects. 
#>  - ind: The unstandardized indirect effects.
#>  - 'm~x','y~m' is/are the path coefficient(s) along the path conditional
#>    on the moderators.

Path Analysis by lavaan::sem()

Suppose we fit the same model, but by path analysis conducted in by structural equation modelling analysis using lavaan::sem().

library(lavaan)
mod <-
"
m ~ x + w1 + x:w1
y ~ m + w2 + m:w2 + x
"
fit_lavaan <- sem(model = mod,
                  data = dat,
                  fixed.x = FALSE)
parameterEstimates(fit_lavaan)[parameterEstimates(fit_lavaan)$op == "~", ]
#>   lhs op  rhs    est    se       z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper
#> 1   m  ~    x -0.634 0.491  -1.293  0.196   -1.596    0.327
#> 2   m  ~   w1 -2.255 0.946  -2.384  0.017   -4.109   -0.401
#> 3   m  ~ x:w1  0.200 0.094   2.129  0.033    0.016    0.384
#> 4   y  ~    m -0.094 0.089  -1.046  0.295   -0.269    0.082
#> 5   y  ~   w2 -0.878 0.088 -10.028  0.000   -1.050   -0.707
#> 6   y  ~ m:w2  0.193 0.012  15.711  0.000    0.169    0.217
#> 7   y  ~    x  0.060 0.088   0.682  0.495   -0.112    0.232

It is not recommended to set se to "boot" for bootstrapping. fit2boot_out_do_boot() can be used to compute only information necessary for this package. It also supports parallel processing.

(Note: Only 500 bootstrap samples are used for illustration. Set R to 2000 or even 5000 in real research.)

fit_lavaan_boot_out <- fit2boot_out_do_boot(fit = fit_lavaan,
                                            R = 500,
                                            seed = 8715,
                                            parallel = TRUE,
                                            ncores = 2)
#> Warning in fit2boot_out_do_boot(fit = fit_lavaan, R = 500, seed = 8715, :
#> 'ncores' >= The number of detected cores (2). The computer may not be responsive
#> when bootstrapping is running.
#> 2 processes started to run bootstrapping.
#> The expected CPU time is about 11.5 second(s).

We can use mod_levels_list() to generate levels of the moderators:

mod_levels <- mod_levels_list("w1", "w2",
                              fit = fit_lavaan,
                              sd_from_mean = c(-1, 1),
                              merge = TRUE)
mod_levels
#>                                w1       w2
#> w1: M+1.0SD; w2: M+1.0SD 6.173157 4.040487
#> w1: M+1.0SD; w2: M-1.0SD 6.173157 2.055091
#> w1: M-1.0SD; w2: M+1.0SD 4.038047 4.040487
#> w1: M-1.0SD; w2: M-1.0SD 4.038047 2.055091

We then use cond_indirect_effects() to compute the conditional indirect effects, with nonparametric bootstrapping confidence intervals:

out_lavaan <- cond_indirect_effects(wlevels = mod_levels,
                                    x = "x",
                                    y = "y",
                                    m = "m",
                                    fit = fit_lavaan,
                                    boot_ci = TRUE,
                                    boot_out = fit_lavaan_boot_out)
out_lavaan
#> 
#> == Conditional indirect effects ==
#> 
#>  Path: x -> m -> y
#>  Conditioned on moderator(s): w1, w2
#>  Moderator(s) represented by: w1, w2
#> 
#>      [w1]    [w2]  (w1)  (w2)   ind  CI.lo CI.hi Sig   m~x   y~m
#> 1 M+1.0SD M+1.0SD 6.173 4.040 0.410 -0.260 1.588     0.599 0.685
#> 2 M+1.0SD M-1.0SD 6.173 2.055 0.181 -0.228 0.962     0.599 0.302
#> 3 M-1.0SD M+1.0SD 4.038 4.040 0.118 -0.565 1.154     0.173 0.685
#> 4 M-1.0SD M-1.0SD 4.038 2.055 0.052 -0.329 0.711     0.173 0.302
#> 
#>  - [CI.lo to CI.hi] are 95.0% percentile confidence intervals by
#>    nonparametric bootstrapping with 500 samples.
#>  - The 'ind' column shows the indirect effects.
#>  - 'm~x','y~m' is/are the path coefficient(s) along the path conditional
#>    on the moderators.

These are the standardized conditional indirect effects:

out_lavaan_std <- cond_indirect_effects(wlevels = mod_levels,
                                        x = "x",
                                        y = "y",
                                        m = "m",
                                        fit = fit_lavaan,
                                        boot_ci = TRUE,
                                        boot_out = fit_lavaan_boot_out,
                                        standardized_x = TRUE,
                                        standardized_y = TRUE)
out_lavaan_std
#> 
#> == Conditional indirect effects ==
#> 
#>  Path: x -> m -> y
#>  Conditioned on moderator(s): w1, w2
#>  Moderator(s) represented by: w1, w2
#> 
#>      [w1]    [w2]  (w1)  (w2)   std  CI.lo CI.hi Sig   m~x   y~m   ind
#> 1 M+1.0SD M+1.0SD 6.173 4.040 0.226 -0.142 1.375     0.599 0.685 0.410
#> 2 M+1.0SD M-1.0SD 6.173 2.055 0.100 -0.122 0.824     0.599 0.302 0.181
#> 3 M-1.0SD M+1.0SD 4.038 4.040 0.065 -0.346 0.990     0.173 0.685 0.118
#> 4 M-1.0SD M-1.0SD 4.038 2.055 0.029 -0.201 0.591     0.173 0.302 0.052
#> 
#>  - [CI.lo to CI.hi] are 95.0% percentile confidence intervals by
#>    nonparametric bootstrapping with 500 samples.
#>  - std: The standardized indirect effects. 
#>  - ind: The unstandardized indirect effects.
#>  - 'm~x','y~m' is/are the path coefficient(s) along the path conditional
#>    on the moderators.

Mediation Only

The function cond_indirect() also supports a path model without moderator. It can be used for complicated models with any number of predictors, mediators, outcome variables, and paths.

This is the sample dataset comes with the package:

library(stdmodsem)
dat <- data_med_complicated
print(head(dat), digits = 3)
#>      x1   x2  m11  m12   m2   y1    y2   c1    c2
#> 1 10.16 4.00 5.84 6.78 7.11 6.06 10.38 5.01  8.20
#> 2 10.89 4.79 4.95 5.81 7.92 5.15  8.52 3.92  9.90
#> 3  9.99 5.79 4.95 4.47 8.21 3.25  7.81 5.91 11.36
#> 4 12.36 4.80 5.56 6.21 8.88 6.27  9.41 6.06 10.49
#> 5 10.85 6.39 6.19 5.39 8.76 5.36  9.84 4.28  9.81
#> 6 10.28 4.58 4.88 4.28 8.50 4.57 10.42 4.71 11.38

Suppose this is the model being fitted:

Multiple Regression by lm()

Although it is common in regression-based mediation analysis to include all possible paths to make a model saturated, we illustrate how to fit the intended model by multiple regression.

lm_m11 <- lm(m11 ~ x1, dat)
lm_m12 <- lm(m12 ~ m11 + x1, dat)
lm_y1 <- lm(y1 ~ m12 + m11 + x1 + x2, dat)
lm_m2 <- lm(m2 ~ x2, dat)
lm_y2 <- lm(y2 ~ m2 + x1 + x2, dat)

These are the coefficients:

  • From x1 to y1:
printCoefmat(summary(lm_m11)$coefficients, digits = 3, signif.legend = FALSE)
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)   1.2765     0.8646    1.48     0.14    
#> x1            0.3589     0.0861    4.17  6.6e-05 ***
printCoefmat(summary(lm_m12)$coefficients, digits = 3, signif.legend = FALSE)
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)    4.648      1.004    4.63  1.1e-05 ***
#> m11            0.527      0.116    4.54  1.6e-05 ***
#> x1            -0.241      0.107   -2.24    0.027 *
printCoefmat(summary(lm_y1)$coefficients, digits = 3, signif.legend = FALSE)
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)   4.1268     1.1442    3.61   0.0005 ***
#> m12           0.2643     0.0930    2.84   0.0055 ** 
#> m11           0.1346     0.1170    1.15   0.2530    
#> x1           -0.0654     0.1008   -0.65   0.5180    
#> x2           -0.1098     0.0989   -1.11   0.2701
  • From x2 to y2:
printCoefmat(summary(lm_m2)$coefficients, digits = 3, signif.legend = FALSE)
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)   6.6204     0.4280   15.47   <2e-16 ***
#> x2            0.2803     0.0866    3.24   0.0016 **
printCoefmat(summary(lm_y2)$coefficients, digits = 3, signif.legend = FALSE)
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)   12.018      1.362    8.82  5.1e-14 ***
#> m2            -0.431      0.121   -3.57  0.00057 ***
#> x1             0.112      0.095    1.18  0.24185    
#> x2             0.048      0.109    0.44  0.66041

To compute indirect effects and form bootstrap confidence intervals, we use cond_indirect_effects(). We first group the lm() outputs to a list by lm2list().

fit_lm <- lm2list(lm_m11, lm_m12, lm_y1, lm_m2, lm_y2)
fit_lm
#> 
#> The models:
#> m11 ~ x1
#> m12 ~ m11 + x1
#> y1 ~ m12 + m11 + x1 + x2
#> m2 ~ x2
#> y2 ~ m2 + x1 + x2

To form bootstrapping confidence intervals, we first repeat the regression analysis in all models by nonparametric bootstrapping and store the results. This can be done by lm2boot_out():

(Note: Only 500 bootstrap samples are used for illustration. Set R to 2000 or even 5000 in real research.)

fit_lm_boot_out_complicated <- lm2boot_out(fit_lm, R = 500, seed = 87415)

We can now compute the indirect effects. There are several possible pathways. cond_indirect() does not require the pathways to be specified before fitting the models. The pathway can be specified when calling it.

For example, suppose we want to estimate the indirect effect through x1 -> m11 -> m12 -> y1. We set x to the start of the pathway, y to the end of the pathway, and m to the sequence of mediators, from left to right:

out_x1y1 <- cond_indirect(x = "x1",
                          y = "y1",
                          m = c("m11", "m12"),
                          fit = fit_lm,
                          boot_ci = TRUE,
                          boot_out = fit_lm_boot_out_complicated)
out_x1y1
#> 
#> == Indirect Effect ==
#>                                            
#>  Path:               x1 -> m11 -> m12 -> y1
#>  Indirect Effect     0.050                 
#>  95.0% Bootstrap CI: [0.014 to 0.110]      
#> 
#> Computation Formula:
#>   (b.m11~x1)*(b.m12~m11)*(b.y1~m12)
#> Computation:
#>   (0.35890)*(0.52697)*(0.26434)
#> 
#> Percentile confidence interval formed by nonparametric bootstrapping
#> with 500 bootstrap samples.
#> 
#> Coefficients of Component Paths:
#>     Path Coefficient
#>   m11~x1       0.359
#>  m12~m11       0.527
#>   y1~m12       0.264

The indirect effect in the pathway x2 -> m2 -> y2 can be estimated similarly:

out_x2y2 <- cond_indirect(x = "x2",
                          y = "y2",
                          m = "m2",
                          fit = fit_lm,
                          boot_ci = TRUE,
                          boot_out = fit_lm_boot_out_complicated)
out_x2y2
#> 
#> == Indirect Effect ==
#>                                        
#>  Path:               x2 -> m2 -> y2    
#>  Indirect Effect     -0.121            
#>  95.0% Bootstrap CI: [-0.224 to -0.029]
#> 
#> Computation Formula:
#>   (b.m2~x2)*(b.y2~m2)
#> Computation:
#>   (0.28033)*(-0.43086)
#> 
#> Percentile confidence interval formed by nonparametric bootstrapping
#> with 500 bootstrap samples.
#> 
#> Coefficients of Component Paths:
#>   Path Coefficient
#>  m2~x2       0.280
#>  y2~m2      -0.431

Suppose we are interested in the indirect effect from x1 to y1 through m11 only, bypassing m12. This can be done by setting m only to m11:

out_x1y1_m11 <- cond_indirect(x = "x1",
                              y = "y1",
                              m = "m12",
                              fit = fit_lm,
                              boot_ci = TRUE,
                              boot_out = fit_lm_boot_out_complicated)
out_x1y1_m11
#> 
#> == Indirect Effect ==
#>                                        
#>  Path:               x1 -> m12 -> y1   
#>  Indirect Effect     -0.064            
#>  95.0% Bootstrap CI: [-0.148 to -0.002]
#> 
#> Computation Formula:
#>   (b.m12~x1)*(b.y1~m12)
#> Computation:
#>   (-0.24074)*(0.26434)
#> 
#> Percentile confidence interval formed by nonparametric bootstrapping
#> with 500 bootstrap samples.
#> 
#> Coefficients of Component Paths:
#>    Path Coefficient
#>  m12~x1      -0.241
#>  y1~m12       0.264

It is also possible to estimate the indirect effect only in a segment of a pathway, for example, from m11 through m12 to y1:

out_m11y1 <- cond_indirect(x = "m11",
                           y = "y1",
                           m = "m12",
                           fit = fit_lm,
                           boot_ci = TRUE,
                           boot_out = fit_lm_boot_out_complicated)
out_m11y1
#> 
#> == Indirect Effect ==
#>                                      
#>  Path:               m11 -> m12 -> y1
#>  Indirect Effect     0.139           
#>  95.0% Bootstrap CI: [0.043 to 0.261]
#> 
#> Computation Formula:
#>   (b.m12~m11)*(b.y1~m12)
#> Computation:
#>   (0.52697)*(0.26434)
#> 
#> Percentile confidence interval formed by nonparametric bootstrapping
#> with 500 bootstrap samples.
#> 
#> Coefficients of Component Paths:
#>     Path Coefficient
#>  m12~m11       0.527
#>   y1~m12       0.264

Path Analysis by lavaan::sem()

Suppose we fit the same model, but by path analysis conducted in by structural equation modelling analysis using lavaan::sem().

library(lavaan)
mod <-
"
m11 ~ x1
m12 ~ m11 + x1
y1 ~ m12 + m11 + x1 + x2
m2 ~ x2
y2 ~ m2 + x1 + x2
"
fit_lavaan <- sem(model = mod,
                  data = dat,
                  fixed.x = FALSE)
parameterEstimates(fit_lavaan)[parameterEstimates(fit_lavaan)$op == "~", ]
#>    lhs op rhs    est    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper
#> 1  m11  ~  x1  0.359 0.085  4.210  0.000    0.192    0.526
#> 2  m12  ~ m11  0.527 0.114  4.613  0.000    0.303    0.751
#> 3  m12  ~  x1 -0.241 0.106 -2.278  0.023   -0.448   -0.034
#> 4   y1  ~ m12  0.281 0.089  3.141  0.002    0.106    0.456
#> 5   y1  ~ m11  0.139 0.113  1.237  0.216   -0.081    0.360
#> 6   y1  ~  x1 -0.066 0.098 -0.675  0.500   -0.258    0.126
#> 7   y1  ~  x2 -0.109 0.096 -1.133  0.257   -0.298    0.080
#> 8   m2  ~  x2  0.280 0.086  3.272  0.001    0.112    0.448
#> 9   y2  ~  m2 -0.506 0.117 -4.324  0.000   -0.735   -0.277
#> 10  y2  ~  x1  0.111 0.093  1.194  0.232   -0.071    0.294
#> 11  y2  ~  x2  0.069 0.107  0.646  0.518   -0.140    0.279

It is not recommended to set se to "boot" for bootstrapping. fit2boot_out_do_boot() can be used to compute only information necessary for this package. It also supports parallel processing.

(Note: Only 500 bootstrap samples are used for illustration. Set R to 2000 or even 5000 in real research.)

fit_lavaan_boot_out_complicated <- fit2boot_out_do_boot(fit = fit_lavaan,
                                            R = 500,
                                            seed = 8715,
                                            parallel = TRUE,
                                            ncores = 2)
#> Warning in fit2boot_out_do_boot(fit = fit_lavaan, R = 500, seed = 8715, :
#> 'ncores' >= The number of detected cores (2). The computer may not be responsive
#> when bootstrapping is running.
#> 2 processes started to run bootstrapping.
#> The expected CPU time is about 6.5 second(s).

We can now compute the indirect effects. There are several possible pathways. cond_indirect() does not require the pathways to be specified before fitting the models. The pathway can be specified when calling it.

For example, suppose we want to estimate the indirect effect through x1 -> m11 -> m12 -> y1. We set x to the start of the pathway, y to the end of the pathway, and m to the sequence of mediators, from left to right:

out_x1y1 <- cond_indirect(x = "x1",
                          y = "y1",
                          m = c("m11", "m12"),
                          fit = fit_lavaan,
                          boot_ci = TRUE,
                          boot_out = fit_lavaan_boot_out_complicated)
out_x1y1
#> 
#> == Indirect Effect ==
#>                                            
#>  Path:               x1 -> m11 -> m12 -> y1
#>  Indirect Effect     0.053                 
#>  95.0% Bootstrap CI: [0.015 to 0.100]      
#> 
#> Computation Formula:
#>   (b.m11~x1)*(b.m12~m11)*(b.y1~m12)
#> Computation:
#>   (0.35890)*(0.52697)*(0.28085)
#> 
#> Percentile confidence interval formed by nonparametric bootstrapping
#> with 500 bootstrap samples.
#> 
#> Coefficients of Component Paths:
#>     Path Coefficient
#>   m11~x1       0.359
#>  m12~m11       0.527
#>   y1~m12       0.281

The indirect effect in the pathway x2 -> m2 -> y2 can be estimated similarly:

out_x2y2 <- cond_indirect(x = "x2",
                          y = "y2",
                          m = "m2",
                          fit = fit_lavaan,
                          boot_ci = TRUE,
                          boot_out = fit_lavaan_boot_out_complicated)
out_x2y2
#> 
#> == Indirect Effect ==
#>                                        
#>  Path:               x2 -> m2 -> y2    
#>  Indirect Effect     -0.142            
#>  95.0% Bootstrap CI: [-0.269 to -0.035]
#> 
#> Computation Formula:
#>   (b.m2~x2)*(b.y2~m2)
#> Computation:
#>   (0.28033)*(-0.50601)
#> 
#> Percentile confidence interval formed by nonparametric bootstrapping
#> with 500 bootstrap samples.
#> 
#> Coefficients of Component Paths:
#>   Path Coefficient
#>  m2~x2       0.280
#>  y2~m2      -0.506

Suppose we are interested in the indirect effect from x1 to y1 through m11 only, bypassing m12. This can be done by setting m only to m11:

out_x1y1_m11 <- cond_indirect(x = "x1",
                              y = "y1",
                              m = "m12",
                              fit = fit_lavaan,
                              boot_ci = TRUE,
                              boot_out = fit_lavaan_boot_out_complicated)
out_x1y1_m11
#> 
#> == Indirect Effect ==
#>                                        
#>  Path:               x1 -> m12 -> y1   
#>  Indirect Effect     -0.068            
#>  95.0% Bootstrap CI: [-0.148 to -0.002]
#> 
#> Computation Formula:
#>   (b.m12~x1)*(b.y1~m12)
#> Computation:
#>   (-0.24074)*(0.28085)
#> 
#> Percentile confidence interval formed by nonparametric bootstrapping
#> with 500 bootstrap samples.
#> 
#> Coefficients of Component Paths:
#>    Path Coefficient
#>  m12~x1      -0.241
#>  y1~m12       0.281

It is also possible to estimate the indirect effect only in a segment of a pathway, for example, from m11 through m12 to y1:

out_m11y1 <- cond_indirect(x = "m11",
                           y = "y1",
                           m = "m12",
                           fit = fit_lavaan,
                           boot_ci = TRUE,
                           boot_out = fit_lavaan_boot_out_complicated)
out_m11y1
#> 
#> == Indirect Effect ==
#>                                      
#>  Path:               m11 -> m12 -> y1
#>  Indirect Effect     0.148           
#>  95.0% Bootstrap CI: [0.053 to 0.260]
#> 
#> Computation Formula:
#>   (b.m12~m11)*(b.y1~m12)
#> Computation:
#>   (0.52697)*(0.28085)
#> 
#> Percentile confidence interval formed by nonparametric bootstrapping
#> with 500 bootstrap samples.
#> 
#> Coefficients of Component Paths:
#>     Path Coefficient
#>  m12~m11       0.527
#>   y1~m12       0.281
